member.summary: Sets the flags associated with the specified asset.
member.remarks: Please note that, for performance reasons, the content manager's internal cache does not normalize asset paths. This means that if you reference the same asset by two different but equivalent paths (i.e. "foo/bar" and "foo\\bar"), each of those paths will represent a separate entry in the cache with separate asset flags.

member.name: M:Ultraviolet.Content.ContentManager.Load``1(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Loads the specified asset file.
member.typeparam: The type of object being loaded.
member.remarks: Content managers maintain a cache of references to all loaded assets, so calling Load() multiple times on a content manager with the same parameter will return the same object rather than reloading the source file.
member.param: The path to the asset to load.
A value indicating whether to add the asset to the manager's cache.

A value indicating whether asset resolution should search the Visual Studio solution directory, rather than the directory containing the application binaries. This is useful primarily for reloading assets while the application is being debugged, and should mostly be avoided unless you know what you're doing.
member.returns: The asset that was loaded from the specified file.

member.name: P:Ultraviolet.Content.ContentManager.IsWatchedContentSupported
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether watched content is supported on the current platform.

member.name: P:Ultraviolet.Content.ContentManager.GloballySuppressDependencyTracking
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether dependency tracking is globally suppressed, reducing memory usage. As a side effect, modifying a dependency of an asset will no longer cause the parent asset to be reloaded in an application which makes use of watched assets.
member.remarks: Setting this property to will not purge any existing dependency tracking caches, so if you turn this on, be sure to do it before loading any content assets.

member.name: P:Ultraviolet.Content.ContentManager.SuppressDependencyTracking
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether dependency tracking is suppressed for this content manager, reducing memory usage. As a side effect, modifying a dependency of an asset will no longer cause the parent asset to be reloaded in an application which makes use of watched assets.
member.remarks: Setting this property to will not purge any existing dependency tracking caches, so if you turn this on, be sure to do it before loading any content assets.

member.name: P:Ultraviolet.Content.ContentManager.BatchDeletedFiles
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the content manager should batch file deletions.
member.remarks: When this property is set to , will not delete files immediately. Instead, it will buffer deletions until the batch is ended. This is useful when, for example, preprocessing a large number of files which depend on the same raw resources; batching deletes ensures that those raw resources remain on disk until all of the assets are preprocessed.

member.name: P:Ultraviolet.Content.ContentManager.RootDirectory
member.summary: Gets the content manager's root directory.

member.name: P:Ultraviolet.Content.ContentManager.FullRootDirectory
member.summary: Gets the full path to the content manager's root directory.

member.name: P:Ultraviolet.Content.ContentManager.OverrideDirectories
member.summary: Gets the content manager's collection of override directories.
member.remarks: Override directories are alternative paths where the content manager will search for asset files. If multiple override directories contain an asset with the same path, directories which have higher indices within this collection will take priority over directories with lower indices, "overriding" the other values of the asset in question. All override directories take precedence over the content manager's root directory.

member.name: T:Ultraviolet.Graphics.Graphics2D.SpriteSortMode
member.summary: Represents the ways in which a sprite batch can sort its sprites.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Graphics.Graphics2D.SpriteSortMode.Deferred
member.summary: Sprites are not drawn until the batch ends, and then are drawn in the order that they were added to the batch.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Graphics.Graphics2D.SpriteSortMode.Immediate
member.summary: Sprites are rendered immediately, without any batching.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Graphics.Graphics2D.SpriteSortMode.Texture
member.summary: Sprites are sorted according to their texture.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Graphics.Graphics2D.SpriteSortMode.BackToFront
member.summary: Sprites are sorted according to their layer depth, from back to front.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Graphics.Graphics2D.SpriteSortMode.FrontToBack
member.summary: Sprites are sorted according to the layer depth, from front to back.

member.name: T:Ultraviolet.Graphics.PrimitiveType
member.summary: Represents the supported primitive types, which specify how vertex data is ordered within a buffer.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Graphics.PrimitiveType.TriangleList
member.summary: The vertex data is ordered as a sequence of triangles, with each triangle described by three new vertices.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Graphics.PrimitiveType.TriangleStrip
member.summary: The vertex data is ordered as a sequence of triangles, with each triangle described by three new vertices and one vertex from the previous triangle.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Graphics.PrimitiveType.LineList
member.summary: The vertex data is ordered as a sequence of line segments, with each line segment described by two new vertices.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Graphics.PrimitiveType.LineStrip
member.summary: The vertex data is ordered as a sequence of line segments, with each line segment described by one new vertex and one vertex from the previous line segment.

member.summary: The render target's data is always discarded when the render target is bound.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Graphics.RenderTargetUsage.PlatformContents
member.summary: The render target's data is preserved on platforms which support doing so in hardware, and discarded on platforms which do not provide such support.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Graphics.RenderTargetUsage.PreserveContents
member.summary: The render target's data is always preserved when the render target is bound. Some platforms may not support this in hardware, leading to performance issues; check the value of to determine whether this is the case.

member.name: T:Ultraviolet.Graphics.StencilOperation
member.summary: Represents the stencil buffer operations.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Graphics.StencilOperation.Decrement
member.summary: Decrements the stencil buffer value, wrapping to the maximum value if the new value is less than 0.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Graphics.StencilOperation.DecrementSaturation
member.summary: Decrements the stencil buffer value, clamping to 0.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Graphics.StencilOperation.Increment
member.summary: Increments the stencil buffer value, wrapping to the minimum value if the new value exceeds the maximum value.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Graphics.StencilOperation.IncrementSaturation
member.summary: Increments the stencil buffer value, clamping to the maximum value.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Graphics.StencilOperation.Invert
member.summary: Inverts the bits of the stencil buffer value.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Graphics.StencilOperation.Keep
member.summary: Preserves the stencil buffer value.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Graphics.StencilOperation.Replace
member.summary: Replaces the stencil buffer value with the reference value.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Graphics.StencilOperation.Zero
member.summary: Sets the stencil buffer value to zero.

member.remarks: Strings parsed by this methods must be comma-delimited lists of three or four color components, in either R, G, B or A, R, G, B format, or a named color.

member.name: P:Ultraviolet.Input.TouchDevice.TapMaximumDistance
member.summary: Gets the maximum distance that a finger can move between its up and down events in order for the input to be considered a "tap." This value is in device-independent pixels (1/96 of an inch).

member.summary: Gets the maximum delay in milliseconds between a finger's up and down events in order for the input to be considered a "tap."

member.name: P:Ultraviolet.Input.TouchDevice.LongPressMaximumDistance
member.summary: Gets the maximum distance that a finger can move before a touch can no longer be considered a long press. This value is in device independent pixels (1/96 of an inch).

member.summary: Raises the event.
member.param: The unique identifier of the gesture which was performed.
The normalized x-coordinate of the gesture's centroid.
The normalized y-coordinate of the gesture's centroid.
The difference between the gesture template and the actual performed gesture; lower is better.
The number of fingers used to perform the gesture.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.International1
member.summary: The first international key.
member.remarks: From http://www.quadibloc.com/comp/scan.htm: INT 1 is the key next to the left shift key on an international keyboard. On many international keyboards, it has the characters < and >, but on the United Kingdom keyboard, it has | and \.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.International2
member.summary: The second international key.
member.remarks: From http://www.quadibloc.com/comp/scan.htm: INT 2 is the lower key of the two to the right of the Enter key on an international keyboard. Confusingly, it, and not the one with | and \ on it in the UK, has the same scan code in some sets as the U. S. | and \ key; and on the Canadian French keyboard, it is this key that has < and > on it. In the United Kingdom, the characters on this key are ~ and #.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.International3
member.summary: The third international key.
member.remarks: From http://www.quadibloc.com/comp/scan.htm: INT 3 is found both on some Brazilian keyboards and on the Japanese keyboard used for a Kanji input method (it has hiragana on the keys, as opposed to the other form of a plain Japanese keyboard with katakana on the keys). On the Japanese keyboard, it has _ and \ on it, and is located next to the right shift key.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.International4
member.summary: The fourth international key.
member.remarks: From http://www.quadibloc.com/comp/scan.htm: INT 4 is also found on the Japanese keyboard. It has | and on it and is located next to the backspace key.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.International5
member.summary: The fifth international key.
member.remarks: From http://www.quadibloc.com/comp/scan.htm: INT 5 is located on the numeric keypad on some Brazilian keyboards. It has the same Group 3 scan code as the extra key on the numeric keypad of 122-key keyboards when the code assignments used for keyboards used with IBM terminals are followed.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.International6
member.summary: The sixth international key.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.International7
member.summary: The seventh international key.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.International8
member.summary: The eighth international key.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.International9
member.summary: The ninth international key.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.Lang1
member.summary: The first language key.
member.remarks: From http://www.usb.org/developers/devclass_docs/Hut1_12v2.pdf: Hangul/English toggle key. This usage is used as an input method editor control key on a Korean language keyboard.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.Lang2
member.summary: The second language key.
member.remarks: From http://www.usb.org/developers/devclass_docs/Hut1_12v2.pdf: Hanja conversion key. This usage is used as an input method editor control key on a Korean language keyboard.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.Lang3
member.summary: The third language key.
member.remarks: From http://www.usb.org/developers/devclass_docs/Hut1_12v2.pdf: Defines the Katakana key for Japanese USB word-processing keyboards.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.Lang4
member.summary: The fourth language key.
member.remarks: From http://www.usb.org/developers/devclass_docs/Hut1_12v2.pdf: Defines the Hiragana key for Japanese USB word-processing keyboards.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.Lang5
member.summary: The fifth language key.
member.remarks: From http://www.usb.org/developers/devclass_docs/Hut1_12v2.pdf: Defines the Zenkaku/Hankaku key for Japanese USB word-processing keyboards.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.Lang6
member.summary: The sixth language key.
member.remarks: From http://www.usb.org/developers/devclass_docs/Hut1_12v2.pdf: Reserved for language-specific functions, such as Front End Processors and Input Method Editors.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.Lang7
member.summary: The seventh language key.
member.remarks: From http://www.usb.org/developers/devclass_docs/Hut1_12v2.pdf: Reserved for language-specific functions, such as Front End Processors and Input Method Editors.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.Lang8
member.summary: The eighth language key.
member.remarks: From http://www.usb.org/developers/devclass_docs/Hut1_12v2.pdf: Reserved for language-specific functions, such as Front End Processors and Input Method Editors.

member.name: F:Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.Lang9
member.summary: The ninth language key.
member.remarks: From http://www.usb.org/developers/devclass_docs/Hut1_12v2.pdf: Reserved for language-specific functions, such as Front End Processors and Input Method Editors.

member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to create a debug context.

member.summary: Gets or sets the levels of debug output which are enabled.

member.name: P:Ultraviolet.UltravioletConfiguration.DebugCallback
member.summary: Gets or sets the delegate that is invoked when a debug message is logged.

member.name: P:Ultraviolet.UltravioletConfiguration.WatchViewFilesForChanges
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether Ultraviolet should watch view definition files and reload them dynamically if changes are detected.

member.name: P:Ultraviolet.UltravioletConfiguration.SupportsHighDensityDisplayModes
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the application supports high-density display modes such as Retina and Retina HD. This allows the application to make use of every physical pixel on the screen, rather than being scaled to use logical pixels.

member.name: P:Ultraviolet.UltravioletConfiguration.Headless
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the Ultraviolet context is headless. A headless context will not create a default window upon initialization.

member.name: P:Ultraviolet.UltravioletConfiguration.EnableServiceMode
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether service mode is enabled.

remarks.para: In service mode, the graphics subsystem is never intialized and no windows are ever created. This is different from headless mode, where the context's primary window is invisible but still exists.

This mode is primarily useful in circumstances where an Ultraviolet-based application has to run in the context of a Windows service, for example on a build server. The Windows security model prevents services from accessing the graphics device, so we need to avoid doing so or else we'll run into errors.

member.name: P:Ultraviolet.UltravioletConfiguration.WindowIsVisible
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the Ultraviolet context's default window is visible at startup. If the context is headless, this setting has no effect.

member.name: P:Ultraviolet.UltravioletConfiguration.WindowIsResizable
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the Ultraviolet context's default window can be resized. If the context is headless, this setting has no effect.

member.name: P:Ultraviolet.UltravioletConfiguration.WindowIsBorderless
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the Ultraviolet context's default window is borderless. If the context is headless, this setting has no effect.

member.name: P:Ultraviolet.UltravioletConfiguration.InitialWindowPosition
member.summary: Gets or sets the intial size and position of the context's primary window.

member.summary: The default client height of a new window.

member.name: T:sspack.ArevaloRectanglePacker
member.summary: Rectangle packer using an algorithm by Javier Arevalo

remarks.para: Original code by Javier Arevalo (jare at iguanademos dot com). Rewritten to C# / .NET by Markus Ewald (cygon at nuclex dot org). The following comments were written by the original author when he published his algorithm.

You have a bunch of rectangular pieces. You need to arrange them in a rectangular surface so that they don't overlap, keeping the total area of the rectangle as small as possible. This is fairly common when arranging characters in a bitmapped font, lightmaps for a 3D engine, and I guess other situations as well.

The idea of this algorithm is that, as we add rectangles, we can pre-select "interesting" places where we can try to add the next rectangles. For optimal results, the rectangles should be added in order. I initially tried using area as a sorting criteria, but it didn't work well with very tall or very flat rectangles. I then tried using the longest dimension as a selector, and it worked much better. So much for intuition...

These "interesting" places are just to the right and just below the currently added rectangle. The first rectangle, obviously, goes at the top left, the next one would go either to the right or below this one, and so on. It is a weird way to do it, but it seems to work very nicely.

The way we search here is fairly brute-force, the fact being that for most offline purposes the performance seems more than adequate. I have generated a japanese font with around 8500 characters and all the time was spent generating the bitmaps.
Also, for all we care, we could grow the parent rectangle in a different way than power of two. It just happens that power of 2 is very convenient for graphics hardware textures.
I'd be interested in hearing of other approaches to this problem. Make sure to post them on http://www.flipcode.com

member.name: T:sspack.ArevaloRectanglePacker.AnchorRankComparer
member.summary: Compares the 'rank' of anchoring points
member.remarks: Anchoring points are potential locations for the placement of new rectangles. Each time a rectangle is inserted, an anchor point is generated on its upper right end and another one at its lower left end. The anchor points are kept in a list that is ordered by their closeness to the upper left corner of the packing area (their 'rank') so the packer favors positions that are closer to the upper left for new rectangles.

member.returns: The relation of the two anchor point's ranks to each other

member.name: T:sspack.RectanglePacker
member.summary: Base class for rectangle packing algorithms

remarks.para: By uniting all rectangle packers under this common base class, you can easily switch between different algorithms to find the most efficient or performant one for a given job.
An almost exhaustive list of packing algorithms can be found here: http://www.csc.liv.ac.uk/~epa/surveyhtml.html
